text: He who fears death will never do anything worth of a living man.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: If it is not right do not do it; if it is not true do not say it.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Freedom is the only worthy goal in life.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: Only the educated are free.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: To be even minded is the greatest virtue.
author: Heraclitus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Heraclitus's Wikipedia page

text: Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: You have power over your mind - not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: The best revenge is not to be like your enemy.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Life is very short and anxious for those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear the future.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: Man is disturbed not by things, but by the view which they take of them.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together, but do so with all your heart.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: Don't seek for everything to happen as you wish it would, but rather wish that everything happens as it actually willâ€”then your life will flow well.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: There is no easy way from the earth to the stars.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: What we do now echoes in eternity.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: When we are no longer able to change a situation, we are challenged to change ourselves.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Pleasure is always derived from something outside you, whereas joy arises from within.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: It is the power of the mind to be unconquerable.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: The best revenge is to be unlike him who performed the injury.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Circumstances don't make the man, they only reveal him to himself.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Men are disturbed not by things, but by the view which they take of them.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: It is not death that a man should fear, but he should fear never beginning to live.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: If you are pained by any external thing, it is not this thing that disturbs you, but your own judgement about it. And it is in your power to wipe out this judgement now.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

text: Don't seek to have events happen as you want, but want them to happen as they do happen, and your life will go well.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: Let us prepare our minds as if we'd come to the very end of life. Let us postpone nothing. Let us balance life's books each day.
author: Seneca
image: Placeholder for image URL from Seneca's Wikipedia page

text: The soul becomes dyed with the colour of its thoughts.
author: Marcus Aurelius
image: Placeholder for image URL from Marcus Aurelius's Wikipedia page

author: Epictetus

text: The way to gain a good reputation is to endeavor to be what you desire to appear.
author: Socrates
image: Placeholder for image URL from Socrates's Wikipedia page

text: To accuse others for one's own misfortunes is a sign of want of education; to accuse oneself shows that one's education has begun; to accuse neither oneself nor others shows that one's education is complete.
author: Epictetus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Epictetus's Wikipedia page

text: No man is happy who does not think himself so.
author: Publilius Syrus
image: Placeholder for image URL from Publilius Syrus's Wikipedia page
